Discovery of Paradigm Dependencies

Jizhou Sun11~{}^{1}, Jianzhong Li22~{}^{2}, Hong Gao33~{}^{3}
School of Computer Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology
92 West Dazhi Street, Nan Gang District, Harbin, China
1 sjzh@hit.edu.cn, 2 lijzh@hit.edu.cn, 3 honggao@hit.edu.cn
Abstract

Missing and incorrect values often cause serious consequences. To deal with these data quality problems, a class of common employed tools are dependency rules, such as Functional Dependencies (FDs), Conditional Functional Dependencies (CFDs) and Edition Rules (ERs), etc. The stronger expressing ability a dependency has, data with the better quality can be obtained. To the best of our knowledge, all previous dependencies treat each attribute value as a non-splittable whole. Actually however, in many applications, part of a value may contains meaningful information, indicating that more powerful dependency rules to handle data quality problems are possible.

In this paper, we consider of discovering such type of dependencies in which the left hand side is part of a regular-expression-like paradigm, named Paradigm Dependencies (PDs). PDs tell that if a string matches the paradigm, element at the specified position can decides a certain other attribute’s value. We propose a framework in which strings with similar coding rules and different lengths are clustered together and aligned vertically, from which PDs can be discovered directly. The aligning problem is the key component of this framework and is proved in NP-Complete. A greedy algorithm is introduced in which the clustering and aligning tasks can be accomplished simultaneously. Because of the greedy algorithm’s high time complexity, several pruning strategies are proposed to reduce the running time. In the experimental study, three real datasets as well as several synthetical datasets are employed to verify our methods’ effectiveness and efficiency.

I Introduction

Statistics show that dirty data is becoming more inevitable and widespread[1, 2], which often causes serious consequences[3, 4] and is expensive to clean. In recent years, the database communities have extensively investigated the problem of dealing with dirty data. Inconsistency and incompleteness are two important aspects of dirty data. A database is inconsistent if it violates some data quality rules such as functional dependencies[5], conditional functional dependencies[6, 7], extended conditional functional dependencies[8] and editing rules[9], fixing rules[10], etc. These rules are also helpful in imputing missing values in an incomplete database.

All these rules exploit relationships between entire attributes, just as defined in relational database where attributes are non-splittable. In many actual applications however, part of an attribute value (especially one with string-type) contains information useful in dealing with incomplete and inconsistent data: manufacturer of a product may name it by the specifications, an ISBN number contains information of the press, DOI number of a paper indicates its publishing information such as the organization, the volume and issue number, etc.

In this paper, we consider of discovering such type of dependencies (Paradigm Dependencies, PDs) from existing datasets. Take a motivating example, in a online shopping website, such as eBay, Amazon and Rakuten, etc., kinds of products with their specifications are listed in the demonstrating pages. However, the specification data may contain errors or even be incomplete. Error information may mislead the customers to buy goods they dislike. Commodities with incomplete information may be neglected in searching. For instance, a customer is looking for computers with memory size equals 16​G​B16𝐺𝐵16GB, a product meeting the requirement will become invisible to the potential buyer if its memory size value is unknown. To avoid these undesirable things from happening, PDs say that part of the id (or type identifier, serial number etc.) of a product can help finding its correct specification values. We employee a real world example to illustrate the feasibility:

Example 1

SL410, T520i and T560 are three notebook types of Thinkpad, as shown in table I. They are not named casually, but have followed some laws: the starting letter stands for its serial, the following numeric digit for Screen Size (4 for 14 inch and 5 for 15 inch), and the second digits of T520i and T560 show that they are firstly sold in 2012 and 2016 respectively.

If the Screen Size value of T560 is unfortunately lost, according to the rule ’The first numeric digit decides the screen size value’ along with T520i’s information, it is easy to derive the missing value, while in the traditional dependencies it is not the case.

From real world applications, several observations can be found in the naming laws:

  • •

    The string values are of different lengths, and digits with the same meaning between different string may occur in different positions.

  • •

    The meaningful digits are often ordered, for example, the digits standing for screen size always appear before those for year.

  • •

    Digits with similar meanings are also similar to each other. In the running example, the first numeric digit stands for screen size. 4 and 5 are not far from each other in the alphabet.

  • •

    Not all tuples obey the same naming law, e.g., New S1 2016 and New S1 2017 are named in a different way from the other three.

It can be found that there are indeed available information in part of a string-type attribute. Meaningful naming laws exist in many areas in different ways, making it hard to obtain manually, and discovering rules automatically is of great significance.

A intuitive solution is clustering and aligning the strings first, then detecting dependencies in each clustered group. By clustering, strings under similar naming laws should be clustered together, and by aligning, characters with similar meaning should be aligned to the same column. In table I, for instance, the first three types may be clustered together and aligned by inserting n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙null values (presented by underlines in column Aligned Type). Dependency relationships between these aligned positions and other attributes can be found and expressed by star-free regular expressions in the detecting step, where several measures are needed, such as support and confidence, etc., similar to those in [11].

Contributions of this paper include:

  • •

    A framework of finding paradigm dependencies is introduced.

  • •

    The problem of string aligning is analysed and proven in NP-Complete.

  • •

    A greedy algorithm is proposed and optimized, by which the aligning and clustering tasks are combined seamlessly.

  • •

    Experiments are conducted on both real and synthetical datasets to verify our methods’ performance.

In the rest of this paper, related work is summarized in section II. In section III, the problems of clustering and aligning, are studied in detail. In section IV we discussed how to find dependencies using the clustered and aligned attributes. In section V are our experimental results and the paper is concluded in VI.

II Related Work

II-A Data Quality Rules

Arenas et al. proposed the concept of consistent query answer with respect to violation of traditional FDs, which identify permanent answers over all possible repairs of a dirty database[12]. In [7], Bohannon et al. introduced CFDs by introducing embedded values into FDs, which have stronger expressing ability. Matching dependencies [13] were introduced to expressing an expert’s knowledge in improving data quality. MDs declare that if two tuples are similar enough on some attributes, they should equal on a certain other attribute. Fan et al. proposed editing rules in [14], which can find certain fixes based on some already known clean information. Given some certain information, editing rules can tell which attributes to fix and how to update them. In [15], fixing rules were proposed. A fixing rule contains an evidence pattern, a set of negative patterns and a fact value. When a tuple fits some negative patterns, the corresponding fixing rule can capture the wrong values and knows how to fix them. For dirty timestamps, temporal constraints were introduced in [16], which declare the distance restrictions between timestamps. Guided by the constraints, the problem of repairing inconsistent timestamps was studied. In [17], regular expressions (REs) can be used to repair dirty data, making them obeying the given REs with minimal revision cost.

II-B Rules Discovery

There are numerous of algorithms proposed for discover FDs, including Tane[18], DepMiner[19], FastFDs[20]. Both Tane and DepMiner search the attribute lattice in a levelwise manner, and can directly obtain minimal FD cover. On the other hand, FastFDs search FDs in a greedy heuristic and depth-first manner, and may lead to non-minimal FDs, a further checking progress is required.

In [11], the problem of discovering CFDs was studied, algorithms for discovering minimal CFDs and dirty values in a data instance were presented. Fan et al. proposed algorithms discovering CFDs analog to those for FDs, i.e., CFDMiner for discovering constant CFDs, and Ctane and FastCFD for ordinary ones in [21].

Besides discovery of FDs and CFDs, there have been researches focus on discovering other rules. Discovery of Denial Constraints (DCs) can be found in [22], an efficient instance-driven discovery algorithm (extended from FastFD) was developed based on a set of inference rules. For temporal rules used in web data cleaning, [23] used machine learning methods such as association measures and outlier detection to handle the discovery problem, which is robust to noise.

III Clustering and Aligning

In this section, we introduce the clustering and aligning problems, and then analyze the difficulties in solving them. Table II summarizes the most important symbols used in the rest sections of the paper.

III-A Clustering

In a good clustering method, two properties are desired:

  • •

    Strings with similar naming law should be clustered together.

  • •

    Strings with different name laws should be clustered into different groups.

For the first property, if strings with similar naming law are separated, the number of strings in a group will be reduced, which means low supports. On the other hand, if strings with different naming laws are grouped together, existing dependencies would be discarded due to underestimated confidences. All these undesired conditions will prevent true dependencies from being discovered.

In a classical clustering, one or more parameters are often required to control the number or sizes of clusters. Unfortunately, in our situation, it is hard to give such a parameter. In addition, simply grouping strings into different sets are insufficient. For example, if dependencies φ1subscript𝜑1\varphi_{1} and φ2subscript𝜑2\varphi_{2} can be discovered from groups G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} respectively, it is possible that by merging G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} into G3subscript𝐺3G_{3}, a new dependency φ3subscript𝜑3\varphi_{3} can be detected.

In this paper, we consider of an adaptive method similar to hierarchical clustering [24, 25, 26]. In our proposed framework, clustering parameters are not required and groups like G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2} and G3subscript𝐺3G_{3} are all maintained.

III-B Aligning

Let 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} be a set of strings over character set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. Given a string s𝑠s, l​e​n​g​t​h​(s)𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑠length(s) is the number of characters (or elements) in s𝑠s, and the i𝑖ith character in s𝑠s is denoted by s​[i]𝑠delimited-[]𝑖s[i], where 1≤i≤l​e​n​g​t​h​(s)1𝑖𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑠1\leq i\leq length(s).

Before the problem definition, we introduce several notations. A distance function over 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is:

d:𝒞×𝒞→[0,+∞]:𝑑→𝒞𝒞0d:\mathcal{C}\times\mathcal{C}\rightarrow[0,+\infty]

In the rest of this paper, d𝑑d is metric by default, if not specified.

Definition 1 (Diameter of Character Sets)

For a set C⊆𝒞∪{n​u​l​l}𝐶𝒞𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙C\subseteq\mathcal{C}\cup\{null\} of characters, the diameter of C𝐶C is the largest distance between every pair of elements in C𝐶C:

D​(C)=maxc1,c2∈C⁡d​(c1,c2)𝐷𝐶subscriptsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2𝐶𝑑subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2D(C)=\max\limits_{c_{1},c_{2}\in C}d(c_{1},c_{2})

Over ’∪\cup’, the diameter satisfies monotonicity and triangle inequality:

Lemma 1

For two arbitrary characters C𝐶C and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}, if C⊆C′𝐶superscript𝐶′C\subseteq C^{\prime} D​(C)≤D​(C′)𝐷𝐶𝐷superscript𝐶′D(C)\leq D(C^{\prime}) always holds. (Proof omitted.)

Lemma 2

For arbitrary three character sets C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} and C3subscript𝐶3C_{3}, the following equations holds:

D​(C1∪C2∪C3)≤D​(C1∪C2)+D​(C2∪C3)𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝐷subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3D(C_{1}\cup C_{2}\cup C_{3})\leq D(C_{1}\cup C_{2})+D(C_{2}\cup C_{3}) (1)
Proof 1

Let c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} be the pair of farthest characters in C1∪C2∪C3subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3C_{1}\cup C_{2}\cup C_{3}. We prove the inequality in all possible cases:

  • •

    If c1,c2∈C1∪C2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2c_{1},c_{2}\in C_{1}\cup C_{2}, then D​(C1∪C2∪C3)=D​(C1∪C2)≤D​(C1∪C2)+D​(C2∪C3)𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝐷subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3D(C_{1}\cup C_{2}\cup C_{3})=D(C_{1}\cup C_{2})\leq D(C_{1}\cup C_{2})+D(C_{2}\cup C_{3}).

  • •

    If c1,c2∈C2∪C3subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3c_{1},c_{2}\in C_{2}\cup C_{3}, the proof is similar.

  • •

    In the rest case, c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} must come from C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C3subscript𝐶3C_{3} respectively, without of loss of generality, assume c1∈C1subscript𝑐1subscript𝐶1c_{1}\in C_{1} and c2∈C3subscript𝑐2subscript𝐶3c_{2}\in C_{3}, for any character c′∈C2superscript𝑐′subscript𝐶2c^{\prime}\in C_{2}: D​(C1∪C2)≥d​(c1,c′)𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝑑subscript𝑐1superscript𝑐′D(C_{1}\cup C_{2})\geq d(c_{1},c^{\prime}) and D​(C2∪C3)≥d​(c′,c2)𝐷subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3𝑑superscript𝑐′subscript𝑐2D(C_{2}\cup C_{3})\geq d(c^{\prime},c_{2}). Meanwhile, because d𝑑d is a metric, we have d​(c1,c′)+d​(c′,c2)≥d​(c1,c2)=D​(C1∪C2∪C3)𝑑subscript𝑐1superscript𝑐′𝑑superscript𝑐′subscript𝑐2𝑑subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3d(c_{1},c^{\prime})+d(c^{\prime},c_{2})\geq d(c_{1},c_{2})=D(C_{1}\cup C_{2}\cup C_{3}), indicating Eq. 1.

Definition 2 (Paradigm)

A paradigm P𝑃P is a set of strings with equal length. The common length of strings in P𝑃P is also called P𝑃P’s length, denoted as l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃length(P), and cardinality of P𝑃P is defined as the number of strings in P𝑃P, denoted as c​a​r​d​(P)𝑐𝑎𝑟𝑑𝑃card(P). The size of P𝑃P is defined by:

s​i​z​e​(P)=∑i=1l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)D​(P​[i])𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃𝐷𝑃delimited-[]𝑖size(P)=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{length(P)}D(P[i])

where P​[i]𝑃delimited-[]𝑖P[i] is the set of characters in the i𝑖ith column:P​[i]={s​[i]|s∈P}𝑃delimited-[]𝑖conditional-set𝑠delimited-[]𝑖𝑠𝑃P[i]=\{s[i]|s\in P\}.

Now we are ready to define the aligning problem formally.

Definition 3 (String Aligning Problem (SAP))

Given a set of strings 𝒮={s1,s2,…,sN}𝒮subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2…subscript𝑠𝑁\mathcal{S}=\{s_{1},s_{2},...,s_{N}\}, a distance function d𝑑d and a threshold t𝑡t, find out a paradigm P={s1′.s2′,…,sN′}P=\{s_{1}^{\prime}.s_{2}^{\prime},...,s_{N}^{\prime}\}, where si′superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖′s_{i}^{\prime} is obtained from sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} by inserting n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙null values, such that s​i​z​e​(P)≤t𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃𝑡size(P)\leq t.

The intuition behind is that similar characters will be aligned into a single column with high probability if the distance function is well designed. Only insertions are allowed because delete or change a character will cause loss of information, which is undesirable. The intuition of using D​(P​[i])𝐷𝑃delimited-[]𝑖D(P[i]) to evaluate the size of a paradigm is that, smaller diameter means higher similariry degree. With s​i​z​e​(P)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃size(P) minimized, similar characters would be aligned together with high possibility. Meanwhile, number of distinct elements in P​[i]𝑃delimited-[]𝑖P[i] should not influence the size too much. For example, if ’111’ and ’333’ is already in P​[i]𝑃delimited-[]𝑖P[i], ’222’ is natural to add into this set, and should not enlarge the size too much. For a contrary example, ∑c1,c2∈Cd​(c1,c2)subscriptsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2𝐶𝑑subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\sum\limits_{c_{1},c_{2}\in C}d(c_{1},c_{2}) does not meet the latter property.

Unfortunately, the SAP is intractable.

Theorem 1

SAP is in NP-Complete, even if d𝑑d is a metric.

Proof 2

The lower and upper bounds of l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃length(P) is maxs∈𝒮⁡l​e​n​g​t​h​(s)subscript𝑠𝒮𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑠\max\limits_{s\in\mathcal{S}}length(s) and ∑s∈𝒮l​e​n​g​t​h​(s)subscript𝑠𝒮𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑠\sum\limits_{s\in\mathcal{S}}length(s) respectively. To prove S​A​P∈N​P𝑆𝐴𝑃𝑁𝑃SAP\in NP, we just guess l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃length(P) and the positions to insert n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙nulls for each string in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, and then verify whether the paradigm size is no more than t𝑡t. Obviously, this can be done by a nondeterministic algorithm in polynomial time, so S​A​P∈N​P𝑆𝐴𝑃𝑁𝑃SAP\in NP

The NP-Completeness can be proven by reduction of the Shortest Common Super-sequence (SCS) problem[27].

The SCS problem is that for a set SS​C​Ssubscript𝑆𝑆𝐶𝑆S_{SCS} of strings, find out a string s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime} with l​e​n​(s′)≤k𝑙𝑒𝑛superscript𝑠′𝑘len(s^{\prime})\leq k, such that for any string s∈SS​C​S𝑠subscript𝑆𝑆𝐶𝑆s\in S_{SCS}, s𝑠s is a subsequence of s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}. Given such a instance of SCS, the construction of String Aligning Problem (SAP) need some tricks. Let SS​A​Psubscript𝑆𝑆𝐴𝑃S_{SAP} be the string set in SAP,

SS​A​P=SS​C​S∪{sn}subscript𝑆𝑆𝐴𝑃subscript𝑆𝑆𝐶𝑆subscript𝑠𝑛S_{SAP}=S_{SCS}\cup\{s_{n}\}

where snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} is a string constituted with k𝑘k identical characters cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n}, which is a new character hasn’t appeared in SS​C​Ssubscript𝑆𝑆𝐶𝑆S_{SCS}.

The distance function d𝑑d is defined as follows:

d​(a,b)={0if a=b1else if a≠b∧(a=n​u​l​l∨b=n​u​l​l)1else if a≠b∧(a=cn∨b=cn)2else𝑑𝑎𝑏cases0if a=b1else if a≠b∧(a=null∨b=null)1else if a≠b∧(a=cn∨b=cn)2elsed(a,b)=\begin{cases}0&\mbox{if $a=b$}\\ 1&\mbox{else if $a\neq b\wedge(a=null\vee b=null)$}\\ 1&\mbox{else if $a\neq b\wedge(a=c_{n}\vee b=c_{n})$}\\ 2&\mbox{else}\end{cases}

The threshold is t=k𝑡𝑘t=k. It is easy to verify that d𝑑d satisfies the triangular inequality, and the construction can be done in polynomial time.

Now we prove that there exists a common super-sequence s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime} for the SCS Problem with l​e​n​g​t​h​(s′)≤k𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎsuperscript𝑠′𝑘length(s^{\prime})\leq k if and only if there exists a paradigm P𝑃P for the SAP Problem with s​i​z​e​(P)≤t𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃𝑡size(P)\leq t.

If. Because snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} is in the string set, and only insertions are allowed, so l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)≥l​e​n​g​t​h​(sn)=k𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑘length(P)\geq length(s_{n})=k. There are exactly k𝑘k columns containing the character cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n}, and everyone of them contains a character different from cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} (i.e., n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙null or a ordinary one). For such a single column, the diameter of the corresponding character set satisfies D​(P​[i])≥1𝐷𝑃delimited-[]𝑖1D(P[i])\geq 1 according to the definition of d𝑑d. Thus we have

s​i​z​e​(P)≥D​(P​[i])×l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)≥1×k=k𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃𝐷𝑃delimited-[]𝑖𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃1𝑘𝑘size(P)\geq D(P[i])\times length(P)\geq 1\times k=k

Along with the If condition s​i​z​e​(P)≤t=k𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃𝑡𝑘size(P)\leq t=k, we have s​i​z​e​(P)=k𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃𝑘size(P)=k, which means l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)=k𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃𝑘length(P)=k and there are no more than 2 different not-null characters at each column. By removing the string snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} from P𝑃P, the rest strings can be directly merged into a super-sequence with length equals k𝑘k.

Only If. If there exists a common super-sequence s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime} for the SCS Problem with l​e​n​g​t​h​(s′)≤k𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎsuperscript𝑠′𝑘length(s^{\prime})\leq k, each string sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} in the string set can be transformed into s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime} by inserting characters into some places. By inserting n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙nulls instead of specified characters, into these places, a new string si′superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖′s_{i}^{\prime} with length equals k𝑘k can be obtained. The new strings along with snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} formed the solution of the SAP Problem. It is obvious that l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)=k𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃𝑘length(P)=k. At each column, there are no two characters with distance larger than 1, so the diameter at each column is no more than 1 and s​i​z​e​(P)≤l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)×1=k𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃1𝑘size(P)\leq length(P)\times 1=k.

Due to its intractability, we consider of greedy solutions. The overall framework and algorithms are introduced in the rest of this section.

III-C Framework

Although the aligning problem is intractable when the number of strings is arbitrary, there exist determined algorithms giving the optimal resolution for a constant number of strings, by Dynamic Programming (DP). Actually, the problem of calculating Edit Distance is a specialization of the aligning problem with two input strings, by specifying the distance between different characters as a constant value. The algorithm is almost all the same, except for some difference in the recursive equation. In our setting, the recursive equation becomes:

s​i​z​ei,j=m​i​n​{s​i​z​ei−1,j+d​(s1​[i],n​u​l​l)s​i​z​ei,j−1+d​(s2​[j],n​u​l​l)sizei−1,j−1+d(s1[i],s2[j]))size_{i,j}=min\begin{cases}size_{i-1,j}+d(s_{1}[i],null)\\ size_{i,j-1}+d(s_{2}[j],null)\\ size_{i-1,j-1}+d(s_{1}[i],s_{2}[j]))\end{cases}

In calculating Edit Distance, the distance function d𝑑d is replaced with the constant 111. In the rest of this paper, in situations of two strings, we use the word ’merge’ instead of ’align’ timely for sake of easy understanding.

Due to tractability of the two-string case and intractability of the general case, a straightforward idea is merging the most similar strings at each step ,i.e., in a greedy manner. The intuition behind is that strings with similar naming law should be merged as early as possible. By doing this, different characters with similar meanings will be aligned together with high possibilities. For example, ’a​b​1​c𝑎𝑏1𝑐ab1c’ and ’a​b​9​c𝑎𝑏9𝑐ab9c’ are obviously obeying the same naming law. If they are merged firstly, the three identical characters ’a𝑎a’, ’b𝑏b’ and ’c𝑐c’ can help us align the different characters ’111’ and ’999’ together.

We say that the aligning result paradigm is merged from the input strings. Generally, merged paradigms can be further merged with other strings or paradigms in similar way. Without loss of generality, a single string can be seen as a initial paradigm. Then we can denote by P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2} the merged paradigm from paradigms P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}. We call P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2} the super-paradigm of P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} (or P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}), and P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} (P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}, resp.) is a sub-paradigm of P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2}.

There are two optional greedy algorithms:

In the first option, two strings in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} are merged into a paradigm P𝑃P, with s​i​z​e​(P)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃size(P) minimized. Next, a string in S𝑆S is selected and merged into P𝑃P, which has never been selected before and with s​i​z​e​(P)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃size(P) still minimized. This process continues until all strings in S𝑆S are merged into P𝑃P. Because a single paradigm is being enlarged in the running time, we call it Single Merge, as shown in algorithm 1.

In the alternative option, each string in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is initialized as a single-string paradigm. All initial paradigms are added into the set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. Then all the paradigms are merged iteratively in a pair-wise manner: at each step, a pair of paradigms P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} are selected and merged into a new one, with s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) minimized. After each merging operation, P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} are removed from 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} and P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2} is added. This process continues until a single paradigm is obtained in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. Because a pair of paradigms are merged at each step, we call it Pairwise Merge, as shown in algorithm 2.

The most time-consuming operation is ’⊎⊎\uplus’, which has a time complexity of O​(n2×M2)𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝑀2O(n^{2}\times M^{2}) where n𝑛n is the length of inputting paradigms, and M𝑀M is the charset size. It can be shown that both Single Merge and Pairwise Merge require O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) times of merging, where N𝑁N is the number of strings |𝒮|𝒮|\mathcal{S}|.

Pairwise Merge is more preferred in this paper, for it naturally fits a Hierarchical Clustering algorithm’s requirement without extra workloads: Each paradigm can be seen as a group of similar strings, if two paradigms P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} are similar enough, they would be merged into a larger one P𝑃P.

Another benefit is that, no clustering parameter is required in the pair-wise framework. By maintaining P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} and P𝑃P in a binary tree structure, discovery dependency becomes straightforward, which will be discussed in section IV.

Due to the high algorithm complexity, we consider several pruning strategies to improve the efficiency, with necessary theoretical supports.

As discussed before, the most time-consuming operation in the pair-wise algorithm is merging of paradigms. More over, merging is carried out for O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) times, even though only N−1𝑁1N-1 of them are actually performed to generate larger paradigms (in Line 6 of algorithm 2) and all of the rest are just for finding out the pair with smallest size (Line 5). So it is possible to reduce the number of useless merging work, and we propose two pruning techniques.

III-D Bound Based Pruning

Instead of calculating the exact size of merging each pair of paradigms, a size interval [l​b,u​b]𝑙𝑏𝑢𝑏[lb,ub] may requires much less computation. We denote the lower and upper bound of s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) by l​b​(P1,P2)𝑙𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2lb(P_{1},P_{2}) and u​b​(P1,P2)𝑢𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2ub(P_{1},P_{2}) respectively. The corresponding interval is denoted by I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}).

The basic idea is that when finding the pair of paradigms with the lowest merging size, we maintain a interval for each candidate pair. If by u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} we denote the lowest upper bound of these intervals, all candidate pairs P1,P2subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1},P_{2} with no higher lower bounds than u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} can be safely pruned in the current iteration. For all of the rest candidates, we call them critical intervals, denoted by 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, tightening their bounds can help pruning more candidates. The tightening process continues until a single candidate left in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, who is right the pair to be merged. We call this the refining process, and illustrate it by example.

Example 2

For 444 candidate intervals I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}), I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}), I​(P2,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3I(P_{2},P_{3}) and I​(P1,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3I(P_{1},P_{3}) in Fig. 1. I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) has the lowest upper bound u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min}, I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}) and I​(P2,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3I(P_{2},P_{3})’s lower bounds are lower than u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min}, it is hard to tell which pair of paradigms is of the lowest size corresponding to them. On the other hand, I​(P1,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3I(P_{1},P_{3})’s lower bound is greater than u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min}, the candidate pair’s merging size must not be the lowest, and can be safely pruned, presented by dotted line. Thus the critical intervals 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} contains I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}), I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}) and I​(P2,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3I(P_{2},P_{3}).

By refining intervals in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, as shown in Fig. 1, u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} becomes lower and I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}) and I​(P2,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3I(P_{2},P_{3})’s lower bounds becomes higher. I​(P2,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3I(P_{2},P_{3})’s lower bound becomes higher than u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} and can be removed from 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} and pruned. By now only two intervals remain in CR, i.e., I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) and I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}). By a further refining, u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} becomes even lower and I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}) is pruned, I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) is identified to be the pair with minimal merging size, as shown in Fig. 1.

Before describing the pruning based algorithm, we introduce several necessary inequalities, and discuss how to evaluating the bounds using to them.

Monotonicity

Size of a paradigm is monotonic.

Lemma 3

Merging a paradigm P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} into P𝑃P doesn’t decrease its size:

s​i​z​e​(P⊎P′)≥s​i​z​e​(P)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎𝑃superscript𝑃′𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃size(P\uplus P^{\prime})\geq size(P) (2)

More over, The size of merging paradigm P𝑃P with a super-paradigm is no less than that of merging with a sub-paradigm.

Lemma 4
s​i​z​e​((P1⊎P2)⊎P3)≥s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3size((P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus P_{3})\geq size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3}) (3)

These two lemmas are obvious and straightforward to prove, thus are omitted here.

Triangular Inequality

Theorem 2 (Triangular Inequality)

The paradigm size satisfies the triangular inequalities under merging operations if d𝑑d is a metric, that is, for three arbitrary paradigms P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} and P3subscript𝑃3P_{3}, the following equations always hold:

s​i​z​e​((P1⊎P2)⊎P3)≤s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)+s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size((P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus P_{3})\leq size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3})+size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) (4)
s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)+s​i​z​e​(P2⊎P3)≥s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2})+size(P_{2}\uplus P_{3})\geq size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3}) (5)
|s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)−s​i​z​e​(P2⊎P3)|≤s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3|size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2})-size(P_{2}\uplus P_{3})|\leq size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3}) (6)

Eq. 4 has a not so triangle form compared with Eq. 5, so we call it the Pseudo Triangular Inequality.

Proof 3

We introduce a new paradigm (P1⊎P2)⊎P1P3subscript⊎subscript𝑃1⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3(P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus_{P_{1}}P_{3}. By the subscribe ’P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}’ it means that when aligning P3subscript𝑃3P_{3} with P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2}, the relative positions are the same as those in P1⊎P3⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3P_{1}\uplus P_{3}. Obviously, s​i​z​e​((P1⊎P2)⊎P3)≤s​i​z​e​((P1⊎P2)⊎P1P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript⊎subscript𝑃1⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3size((P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus P_{3})\leq size((P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus_{P_{1}}P_{3}). It becomes sufficient to prove

s​i​z​e​((P1⊎P2)⊎P1P3)≤s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)+s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript⊎subscript𝑃1⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size((P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus_{P_{1}}P_{3})\leq size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3})+size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2})

In (P1⊎P2)⊎P1P3subscript⊎subscript𝑃1⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3(P_{1}\uplus P_{2})\uplus_{P_{1}}P_{3}, for a random position p​o​s𝑝𝑜𝑠pos, we denote the character sets at p​o​s𝑝𝑜𝑠pos coming from P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} and P3subscript𝑃3P_{3} by C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} and C3subscript𝐶3C_{3} respectively for ease. Because the only change of P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2} is inserting a set of n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙nulls (whose size equals 00), s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size({P_{1}\uplus P_{2}}) remains unchanged. It becomes sufficient to prove D​(C1∪C2∪C3)≤D​(C1∪C3)+D​(C1∪C2)𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶3𝐷subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2D(C_{1}\cup C_{2}\cup C_{3})\leq D(C_{1}\cup C_{3})+D(C_{1}\cup C_{2}), which directly holds according to Eq. 1.

Eq. 5 can be directly proved using Eq. 4 and Eq. 3, and Eq. 6 can be inferred from Eq. 5 by element substitutions.

In our framework, s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) is likely to be unavailable, instead, the bounds l​b​(P1,P2)𝑙𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2lb(P_{1},P_{2}) and u​b​(P1,P2)𝑢𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2ub(P_{1},P_{2}) are maintained. Thus, the previous inequalities should be adjust before using, for example, Eq. 4 becomes l​b​((P1⊎P2),P3)≤u​b​(P1,P3)+u​b​(P1,P2)𝑙𝑏⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑢𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3𝑢𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2lb((P_{1}\uplus P_{2}),P_{3})\leq ub(P_{1},P_{3})+ub(P_{1},P_{2}). In the rest of this paper, we refer the inequalities by their adjusted versions, if not specified explicitly.

Eq. 2, 3 and 4 provide bounds when a new merged paradigm is added into 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. If P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} are identified as the pair with minimal size, then after adding P1⊎P2⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\uplus P_{2} into 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, l​b​(P1⊎P2,P)𝑙𝑏⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑃lb(P_{1}\uplus P_{2},P) and u​b​(P1⊎P2,P′)𝑢𝑏⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2superscript𝑃′ub(P_{1}\uplus P_{2},P^{\prime}) should be initialized for each P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}.

According to Eq. 2, s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) is a candidate value of l​b​(P1⊎P2,P′)𝑙𝑏⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2superscript𝑃′lb(P_{1}\uplus P_{2},P^{\prime}). With Eq. 3, s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3}) (similarly, as well as s​i​z​e​(P2⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3size(P_{2}\uplus P_{3})) can be another candidate value of l​b​(P1⊎P2,P′)𝑙𝑏⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2superscript𝑃′lb(P_{1}\uplus P_{2},P^{\prime}). For u​b​(P1⊎P2,P′)𝑢𝑏⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2superscript𝑃′ub(P_{1}\uplus P_{2},P^{\prime}), Eq. 4 asserts that s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)+s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1}\uplus P_{3})+size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) and s​i​z​e​(P2⊎P3)+s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{2}\uplus P_{3})+size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) are available upper bounds.

On the other hand, Eq 5 and 6 play an important role when the former three are not applicable. For instance, before the iterations begin, each paradigm contains a single string, while Eq. 2-4 focus on new merged paradigms. In addition, while refining 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, no new paradigm is created and the critical intervals require tightening. By calculating the exact values of s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2}) and s​i​z​e​(P2⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3size(P_{2}\uplus P_{3}), interval of s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P3)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3size({P_{1}\uplus P_{3}}) would be tightened.

Now we discuss how to find pairs whose sizes should be exactly evaluated to refine the critical set 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}. By 𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)𝒫𝒞ℛ\mathcal{P(CR)}, we denote the set of paradigms involved in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}. To tighten I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) for all pairs P1,P2∈𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝒫𝒞ℛP_{1},P_{2}\in\mathcal{P(CR)}, we propose a single-pivot-star refining technique: Select a paradigm P∈𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)𝑃𝒫𝒞ℛP\in\mathcal{P(CR)} as the pivot, then evaluate the exact value of s​i​z​e​(P,P′)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃superscript𝑃′size(P,P^{\prime}) for each paradigm P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} in 𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)𝒫𝒞ℛ\mathcal{P(CR)} except P𝑃P it self. By doing so, bounds for each pair of paradigms P1,P2subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1},P_{2} can be updated by:

l​b′​(P1,P2)={s​i​z​e​(P1,P2)if P∈{P1,P2}.|s​i​z​e​(P1,P)−s​i​z​e​(P,P2)|else𝑙superscript𝑏′subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2cases𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2if P∈{P1,P2}.𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript𝑃1𝑃𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃subscript𝑃2elselb^{\prime}(P_{1},P_{2})=\begin{cases}size(P_{1},P_{2})&\mbox{if $P\in\{P_{1},P_{2}\}$.}\\ |size(P_{1},P)-size(P,P_{2})|&\mbox{else}\end{cases}

and

u​b′​(P1,P2)={s​i​z​e​(P1,P2)if P∈{P1,P2}.s​i​z​e​(P1,P)+s​i​z​e​(P,P2)else𝑢superscript𝑏′subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2cases𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2if P∈{P1,P2}.𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript𝑃1𝑃𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃subscript𝑃2elseub^{\prime}(P_{1},P_{2})=\begin{cases}size(P_{1},P_{2})&\mbox{if $P\in\{P_{1},P_{2}\}$.}\\ size(P_{1},P)+size(P,P_{2})&\mbox{else}\end{cases}

We demonstrate this by an example

Example 3

In Fig. 2, there are 555 paradigms, presented by nodes, among which P0subscript𝑃0P_{0} is selected as the pivot. s​i​z​e​(P0⊎P1)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃0subscript𝑃1size(P_{0}\uplus P_{1}), s​i​z​e​(P0⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃0subscript𝑃2size(P_{0}\uplus P_{2}), s​i​z​e​(P0⊎P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃0subscript𝑃2size(P_{0}\uplus P_{2}) and s​i​z​e​(P0⊎P4)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃0subscript𝑃4size(P_{0}\uplus P_{4}) are evaluated exactly (equal 1.51.51.5, 222, 222 and 111 respectively), presented by solid lines and shaped like a star. All other pairs’ bounds are obtained according to Eq. 5 and 6: I​(P1,P2)=I​(P1,P3)=[0.5,3.5],I​(P1,P4)=[0.5,2.5],I​(P2,P3)=[0,4],I​(P2,P4)=I​(P3,P4)=[1,3]formulae-sequence𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃30.53.5formulae-sequence𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃40.52.5formulae-sequence𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃304𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃4𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃413I(P_{1},P_{2})=I(P_{1},P_{3})=[0.5,3.5],I(P_{1},P_{4})=[0.5,2.5],I(P_{2},P_{3})=[0,4],I(P_{2},P_{4})=I(P_{3},P_{4})=[1,3].

The intuition of single-pivot-star refining is that, all pairs’ bounds can be evaluated exactly or by Eq. 5 and 6 directly. Meanwhile, it carries out the minimal number (equals |𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)|−1𝒫𝒞ℛ1|\mathcal{P(CR)}|-1) of necessary merging operations, because connecting all paradigms requires that much edges.

Pivot Selection

Now we show how to select a pivot wisely. C​R𝐶𝑅CR is a set of intervals overlapping with each other. From Fig. 1, it can be shown that tightening intervals help reducing 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}. Thus we evaluate a pivot’s ability of shortening intervals. A score function on 𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)𝒫𝒞ℛ\mathcal{P(CR)} is introduced:

s​c​o​r​e​(P)=∑I​(P1,P2)∈𝒞​ℛ,P∈{P1,P2}u​b​(P1,P2)−l​b​(P1,P2)𝑠𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑒𝑃subscriptformulae-sequence𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝒞ℛ𝑃subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑢𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑙𝑏subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2score(P)=\sum\limits_{I(P_{1},P_{2})\in\mathcal{CR},P\in\{P_{1},P_{2}\}}{ub(P_{1},P_{2})-lb(P_{1},P_{2})} (7)

That is, sum of widths of intervals that are related with P𝑃P. Then the paradigm with max score is selected as the pivot: p​i​v​o​t=argmaxPs​c​o​r​e​(P)𝑝𝑖𝑣𝑜𝑡subscriptargmax𝑃𝑠𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑒𝑃pivot=\mathop{\operatorname*{argmax}_{P}score(P)}. In single-pivot-start refining, we can see that all intervals about P𝑃P shrink into exact values, the corresponding total width reduced equals s​c​o​r​e​(P)𝑠𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑒𝑃score(P), which should better be maximized.

By now, pruning techniques based on lower and upper bounds have been discussed. Next, we introduce Independency Base Pruning, to improve the algorithm efficiency further.

III-E Independency Based Pruning

When identifying 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, up to O​(|𝒫|2)𝑂superscript𝒫2O(|\mathcal{P}|^{2}) intervals are identified to be critical in the worst case. That is the case if almost all paradigm pairs are of the same size. It is not hard to get that |𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)|≥|𝒞​ℛ|𝒫𝒞ℛ𝒞ℛ|\mathcal{P(CR)}|\geq|\mathcal{CR}|. Meanwhile, in the refining process, up to |𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)|−1𝒫𝒞ℛ1|\mathcal{P(CR)}|-1 actual merging operations are required and (𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)|−1)×(𝒫​(𝒞​ℛ)|−2)/2conditional𝒫𝒞ℛ1conditional𝒫𝒞ℛ22(\mathcal{P(CR)}|-1)\times(\mathcal{P(CR)}|-2)/2 intervals are to be refined. As a result, O​(|𝒞​ℛ|)𝑂𝒞ℛO(|\mathcal{CR}|) merging and O​(|𝒞​ℛ|2)𝑂superscript𝒞ℛ2O(|\mathcal{CR}|^{2}) refining operations are performed, this will degrade the efficiency seriously.

To reduce 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}’s cardinality, it can be identified more wisely. By Iu​msubscript𝐼𝑢𝑚I_{um} we denote the interval from which u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} is found, e.g., I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) in Fig. 1. We consider of verifying those intervals who are dependent with Iu​msubscript𝐼𝑢𝑚I_{um} only. By ’dependent’, it means that one interval shares a common paradigm with another. We demonstrate this by an example:

Example 4

In Fig. 1 of Example 2, Iu​msubscript𝐼𝑢𝑚I_{um} is I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) because it holds the lowest upper bound. I​(P1,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃3I(P_{1},P_{3}) and I​(P2,P3)𝐼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3I(P_{2},P_{3}) are dependent with I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}), because they share a common paradigm with I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) (i.e., P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} respectively). On the other hand, I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}) is independent with I​(P1,P2)𝐼subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2I(P_{1},P_{2}) because they share no common paradigm. With independency based pruning, I​(P3,P4)𝐼subscript𝑃3subscript𝑃4I(P_{3},P_{4}) is not added into C​R𝐶𝑅CR, and the refining terminates after a single refining process (see Fig. 1).

Under this pruning strategy, a paradigm pair with higher size may be merged earlier than another pair with lower size. Fortunately, this adjustment doesn’t affect the final result, which can be proved theoretically.

Theorem 3

If P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} is of the minimal merging size among all pairs involving P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} or P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}, they will be actually merged sooner or later.

Proof 4

Relationship between P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} and all other paradigms is illustrated in Fig. 3. P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} have the minimal merging size with each other. Note that there probably exist pairs having lower merging size than s​i​z​e​(P1,P2)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2size(P_{1},P_{2}).

Now it can be shown that P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} will be merged eventually, no matter sooner or later. When merging occurs between other paradigms, say P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} and P′′superscript𝑃′′P^{\prime\prime}, P′⊎P′′⊎superscript𝑃′superscript𝑃′′P^{\prime}\uplus P^{\prime\prime} is added in to 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, we have s​i​z​e​(P1⊎P2)<s​i​z​e​(P1⊎(P′⊎P′′))≤s​i​z​e​(P1,P′)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒⊎subscript𝑃1⊎superscript𝑃′superscript𝑃′′𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃′size(P_{1}\uplus P_{2})<size(P_{1}\uplus(P^{\prime}\uplus P^{\prime\prime}))\leq size(P_{1},P^{\prime}), according to Eq. 3. P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} still have the minimal merging size with each other. Thus, it can be concluded that when P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} (or P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}) is merged, it must be merged with P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} (P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} resp.), so it makes no difference by merging them sooner or later.

III-F Algorithm Flow

Our pruning based algorithm is illustrated in Algorithm 3. In lines 1-3, The paradigm set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} as well as size intervals are initialized. Then paradigms in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} are merged in pair-wise manner iteratively, until a single one is obtained (Lines 4-15). In each iteration, the critical interval set 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} is identified (Lines 5-6). Then 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} is refined iteratively until a single interval left (Lines 7-10). In line 8, a pivot paradigm is selected according to Eq. 7. Then intervals in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} are refined by calling algorithm 4, and u​bm​i​n𝑢subscript𝑏𝑚𝑖𝑛ub_{min} and 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} are updated accordingly (Line 10).

After the refining process terminated, from the single interval in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, two paradigms can be identified to be merged into a new one (Line 11), the paradigm set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is updated (Lines 12 and 13). For the new added paradigm P𝑃P, the sizes’ bounds of merging it with others are evaluated (Lines 14 and 15).

Algorithm 4 provides a procedure tightening intervals in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR} by P𝑃P. For each paradigm P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} involved in 𝒞​ℛ𝒞ℛ\mathcal{CR}, the exact value of s​i​z​e​(P,P′)𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒𝑃superscript𝑃′size(P,P^{\prime}) is calculated (Lines 2-3). With these exact values, other paradigm-pairs’ sizes are updated using Eq. 5 and 6, if they make the interval tighter (Lines 5-6).

By pruning, number of merging times in Algorithms 3 is no more than that in Algorithm 2. Meanwhile, at least one merging operation is performed in lines 7-10. We can conclude that Algorithm 3 always terminates.

IV Finding Paradigm-Dependency

Given a paradigm P𝑃P, c​a​r​d​(P)𝑐𝑎𝑟𝑑𝑃card(P) can be very large, making it hard to express. We consider of compacting P𝑃P by deduplicating in columns, denoted by C​o​m​p​(P)𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑃Comp(P). For instance, in Table I of Example 1, Type of the first three tuples are aligned into a new column Aligned Type (a paradigm P𝑃P). By duplication, we get: C​o​m​p​(P)={S​T}​[L]​{45}​{126}​0​[i]𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑃𝑆𝑇delimited-[]𝐿451260delimited-[]𝑖Comp(P)=\{ST\}[L]\{45\}\{126\}0[i]. Actually it’s of the form of star-free Regular Expressions: exactly one of the elements in braces ’{}\{\}’ is supposed to appear, and no more than one of elements in square brackets ’[][]’ is supposed. For instance, TL510i is a string matches C​o​m​p​(P)𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑃Comp(P).

By now, with paradigms generated in the previous section, the notion of Paradigm Dependencies can be defined.

Definition 4 (Paradigm Dependency)

a paradigm dependency φ𝜑\varphi is of the form (P,i)→A→𝑃𝑖𝐴(P,i)\rightarrow A. Where P𝑃P is a paradigm generated on the a string-type attribute S​T​R𝑆𝑇𝑅STR, i𝑖i is a integer between 111 and l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃length(P), a​t​t𝑎𝑡𝑡att and S​T​R𝑆𝑇𝑅STR are attributes in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, which is the attribute set on relation R𝑅R.

The semantic of φ𝜑\varphi is that, given an instance D𝐷D on R𝑅R, for any two tuples t1subscript𝑡1t_{1} and t2subscript𝑡2t_{2} in D𝐷D with their S​T​R𝑆𝑇𝑅STR values matching C​o​m​p​(P)𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑃Comp(P), and c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} are the two characters aligned to the i𝑖ith column of P𝑃P in t1​[S​T​R]subscript𝑡1delimited-[]𝑆𝑇𝑅t_{1}[STR] and t2​[S​T​R]subscript𝑡2delimited-[]𝑆𝑇𝑅t_{2}[STR] respectively, if c1≠c2∨t1​[A]=t2​[A]subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝑡1delimited-[]𝐴subscript𝑡2delimited-[]𝐴c_{1}\neq c_{2}\vee t_{1}[A]=t_{2}[A] always holds, we say that D𝐷D satisfies φ𝜑\varphi, denoted as D⊢φproves𝐷𝜑D\vdash\varphi.

The intuitive meaning of φ𝜑\varphi is that, characters in S​T​R𝑆𝑇𝑅STR aligned to the specified location i𝑖i can decide the values of A𝐴A.

Before defining the discovery problem of paradigm dependencies, several measures are necessary for finding high quality dependencies.

Support is defined as the maximum number of tuples satisfying the dependency:

S​u​p​p​o​r​t​(D,φ)=maxD′⊆D,D′⊢φ⁡|D|𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑡𝐷𝜑subscriptprovessuperscript𝐷′𝐷superscript𝐷′𝜑𝐷Support(D,\varphi)=\max\limits_{D^{\prime}\subseteq D,D^{\prime}\vdash\varphi}{|D|}

D𝐷D is the dataset from which dependencies are discovered. Support is a frequency measure based on the idea that values which occur together frequently have more evidence to substantiate that they are correlated and hence are more interesting. A threshold s​u​p​p​o​r​tm​i​n𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟subscript𝑡𝑚𝑖𝑛support_{min} should be specified and every dependency discovered on D𝐷D should have a no lower support.

Confidence of φ𝜑\varphi over D𝐷D can be stated as:

C​o​n​f​i​d​e​n​c​e​(D,φ)=S​u​p​p​o​r​t​(D,φ)|D|𝐶𝑜𝑛𝑓𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑛𝑐𝑒𝐷𝜑𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑡𝐷𝜑𝐷Confidence(D,\varphi)=\frac{Support(D,\varphi)}{|D|}

it measures the level to which D𝐷D satisfies φ𝜑\varphi. It is employed in this paper for two reasons: 1) D𝐷D may contains incorrect values and 2) characters with the same meaning are not always aligned to the same column. Again, a threshold c​o​n​f​i​d​e​n​c​em​i​n𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑓𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑛𝑐subscript𝑒𝑚𝑖𝑛confidence_{min} should be specified to filter the discovered dependencies.

It is possible that domain of the right hand attribute A𝐴A is very small. For a real world instance, there are only two mainstream cpu brands (AMD and Intel) for computers. Thus In D𝐷D, it becomes possible that only a single value occurs on the right hand side attribute A𝐴A. In this situation, all dependencies with A𝐴A on the right hand side are satisfied by D𝐷D, which have no meaningful information and should be discarded. To handle this, the Diversity measure is introduced:

D​i​v​e​r​s​i​t​y​(D,φ)=σ​(D​[A])𝐷𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑡𝑦𝐷𝜑𝜎𝐷delimited-[]𝐴Diversity(D,\varphi)=\sigma(D[A])

where D​(A)𝐷𝐴D(A) is the set of values of attribute A𝐴A occurred in D𝐷D, and by σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot), it counts the number of distinct values.

On the other hand, it is also possible that there are so many different characters occurring on the i𝑖ith column in the aligned strings, that any pair of tuples have different values on the left hand side. That means, c1≠c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1}\neq c_{2} in Definition 4 always hold, as a sequence, all dependency with the i𝑖ithe column on the left hand side are always satisfied. They are meaningless and should be discarded, by introducing the measure InnerSupport:

I​n​n​e​r​S​u​p​p​o​r​t​(D,φ)=maxD′⊆D,D′⊢φ⁡η​(P​[i])𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑟𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑡𝐷𝜑subscriptprovessuperscript𝐷′𝐷superscript𝐷′𝜑𝜂𝑃delimited-[]𝑖InnerSupport(D,\varphi)=\max\limits_{D^{\prime}\subseteq D,D^{\prime}\vdash\varphi}{\eta(P[i])}

where φ𝜑\varphi is defined on P𝑃P and i𝑖i, and η​(⋅)𝜂⋅\eta(\cdot) denotes the number of the most frequent value’s occurrence. For example, η​(a,a,b,a,b,a,c,d)=4𝜂𝑎𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑐𝑑4\eta({a,a,b,a,b,a,c,d})=4 because a𝑎a is most frequent value and it occurs for 444 times. Similarly, the corresponding threshold I​n​n​e​r​S​u​pm​i​n𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑟𝑆𝑢subscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛InnerSup_{min} is required.

Now we are ready to define the discovery problem formally.

Definition 5 (Discovery of Paradigm Dependencies)

Given a dataset D𝐷D on attribute set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, P𝑃P is a paradigm aligned on D​[S​T​R]𝐷delimited-[]𝑆𝑇𝑅D[STR], where S​T​R𝑆𝑇𝑅STR is a string-type attribute in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, as well as four measure thresholds: S​u​p​p​o​r​tm​i​n𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟subscript𝑡𝑚𝑖𝑛Support_{min}, C​o​n​f​i​d​e​n​c​em​i​n𝐶𝑜𝑛𝑓𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑛𝑐subscript𝑒𝑚𝑖𝑛Confidence_{min}, D​i​v​e​r​s​i​t​ym​i​n𝐷𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑡subscript𝑦𝑚𝑖𝑛Diversity_{min} and I​n​n​e​r​S​u​pm​i​n𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑟𝑆𝑢subscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛InnerSup_{min}. Find out all paradigm dependencies φ:(P,i)→A:𝜑→𝑃𝑖𝐴\varphi:(P,i)\rightarrow A satisfying the thresholds, where i∈{1,2,…,l​e​n​g​t​h​(P)}𝑖12…𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑃i\in\{1,2,...,length(P)\} and A∈𝒜𝐴𝒜A\in\mathcal{A}.

Each tuple tl∈Dsubscript𝑡𝑙𝐷t_{l}\in D claims a key-value pair for dependency φ𝜑\varphi, denoted by ⟨kl,vl⟩subscript𝑘𝑙subscript𝑣𝑙\langle k_{l},v_{l}\rangle, thus a multiple set of key-value pairs can be obtained: Claims={<kl,vl>|tl∈D}Claims=\{<k_{l},v_{l}>|t_{l}\in D\}. It is not hard to obtain the support measure from C​l​a​i​m​s𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠Claims:

S​u​p​p​o​r​t​(D,φ)=∑kmax⟨k,v⟩∈C​l​a​i​m​s⁡𝒩​(⟨k,v⟩,C​l​a​i​m​s)𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑡𝐷𝜑subscript𝑘subscript𝑘𝑣𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠𝒩𝑘𝑣𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠Support(D,\varphi)=\sum\limits_{k}{\max\limits_{\langle k,v\rangle\in Claims}{\mathcal{N}(\langle k,v\rangle,Claims)}}

where 𝒩​(⟨k,v⟩,C​l​a​i​m​s)𝒩𝑘𝑣𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠\mathcal{N}(\langle k,v\rangle,Claims) denotes the number of occurrences of ⟨k,v⟩𝑘𝑣\langle k,v\rangle in C​l​a​i​m​s𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠Claims.

Then the confidence and diversity measures can be directly evaluated by their definitions.

Similar to support, inner support can be calculated by:

S​u​p​p​o​r​t​(D,φ)=max⟨k,v⟩∈C​l​a​i​m​s⁡𝒩​(⟨k,v⟩,C​l​a​i​m​s)𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑡𝐷𝜑subscript𝑘𝑣𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠𝒩𝑘𝑣𝐶𝑙𝑎𝑖𝑚𝑠Support(D,\varphi)=\max\limits_{\langle k,v\rangle\in Claims}{\mathcal{N}(\langle k,v\rangle,Claims)}

Actually, support and inner support are maximized meanwhile, i.e., on the same subset D′⊆Dsuperscript𝐷′𝐷D^{\prime}\subseteq D.

A straightforward method is evaluating the measurements on each paradigm P𝑃P generated in Algorithm 3 (Line 11), then discard unqualified ones.

There are two prune strategies to reduce useless work: 1) a paradigm P𝑃P with c​a​r​d​(P)≤s​u​p​p​o​r​tm​i​n𝑐𝑎𝑟𝑑𝑃𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟subscript𝑡𝑚𝑖𝑛card(P)\leq support_{min} can be discarded directly, because it is obvious that the support measure cannot be higher than c​a​r​d​(P)𝑐𝑎𝑟𝑑𝑃card(P) and 2) if both φ1:(P1,i1)→A:subscript𝜑1→subscript𝑃1subscript𝑖1𝐴\varphi_{1}:(P_{1},i_{1})\rightarrow A and φ2:(P2,i2)→A:subscript𝜑2→subscript𝑃2subscript𝑖2𝐴\varphi_{2}:(P_{2},i_{2})\rightarrow A are discarded due to low confidence, then φ:((P1⊎P2),i)→A:𝜑→⊎subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2𝑖𝐴\varphi:((P_{1}\uplus P_{2}),i)\rightarrow A has a low confidence measure as well, where the i1subscript𝑖1i_{1}th column of P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and the i2subscript𝑖2i_{2}th column of P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} are aligned into the i𝑖ith column of P𝑃P. It is not hard to prove and we omit the detailed discussion here due to space limitation.

V experiments

V-A Settings

All experiments were conducted on a machine with 256 2.2GHz Intel cpus (among which, only one cpu is used) and 3TB of RAM. All algorithms had been implemented in Java with heap size set to 128GB. The underlying operating system is CentOS.

Real Datasets

We used three real datasets, namely the Notebook, CPU and RAM datasets. All of these datasets were manually collected from the corresponding official websites. Each record contains a string-type attribute, which is the product type, id or serial number, and can be seen as an identifier of that product. We call this attribute ID, values on which are to be aligned. Other attributes are used to describe specification of a product. For example, in the Notebook dataset, there are attributes such as Screen Size, Model of Video Card, CPU’s frequency, etc. Not all attribute values for a product can be obtained, and when finding paradigm dependencies, key-value pairs containing n​u​l​l𝑛𝑢𝑙𝑙nulls are simply discarded. Statistical information of the three subsets is listed in Table III.

V-A1 Synthetic Datasets

Synthetic data were used in the efficiency evaluation for the aligning problem, so only those values on ID were generated. When synthesizing datasets, several parameters were used, namely length of ID (l𝑙l), Number of Records (N𝑁N), Number of Clusters (C​N𝐶𝑁CN) and Variation Ratio (σ𝜎\sigma). The charset for generating strings is C​h​a​r​s​e​t={0,1,…,9,a,b,…​z,−,_,/,…}𝐶ℎ𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑒𝑡01…9𝑎𝑏…𝑧_…Charset=\{0,1,...,9,a,b,...z,-,\_,/,...\}, i.e., numeric digits, letters and several other visible characters in ASCII.

Firstly, a single string with length l𝑙l was generated for each cluster, with characters randomly selected from C​h​a​r​s​e​t𝐶ℎ𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑒𝑡Charset. This string was used as a seed to generate more similar strings for the corresponding cluster.

Nextly, N𝑁N strings were generated according to seeds generated before. For each string, we select a seed at random, with uniform probabilities. Then by copying the seed with variation, a new string can be generated similar to that seed. By variation, it means that when copying, each character can be changed with a probability σ𝜎\sigma. For similarity, a character is more probable to be changed into one with the same type. For example, if the character ’f’ is changed, it will change into ’d’ more possible than into ’0’ or ’_’. To simulate real world situations, a character is also possible to be deleted from the string. By doing this, similar strings with different length can be obtained. When a new string is generated, it can also be used as a seed, to avoid the situation that all strings in a cluster generated from the same single seed.

Table IV shows some parameters considered in the experiments. When not explicitly stated, we use the default configuration value (highlighted in bold).

V-A2 Algorithms

The Single-Merge based algorithm (Algorithm 1) does not fit our framework in aligning and clustering simultaneously, thus it was not evaluated experimentally. The Pairwise merging algorithm (Algorithm 2) provides the basic idea of this paper, it was considered as a baseline algorithm to evaluate the pruning techniques’ efficiency. Two pruning strategies were proposed on the baseline algorithm, namely bound based and independency based techniques. The independency based one is very efficiency, such that when abandoned, the algorithm becomes extremely inefficient. This made it hard to be evaluated in an acceptable time period, so we use this technique in default in all versions of the pruning based method.

As discussed before, all inequalities for bound based pruning are used either in the refining phase (i.e., Eq. 6 and 5), or when new paradigm is created (i.e., Eq. 2-4). The former ones are basic of the pruning based method, so they were used by default.

We evaluated two versions of the pruning based algorithm: has or hasn’t used Eq. 2-4, the former is denoted by Prunning+ and the latter by Pruning-.

V-B Discovered Rules

In discovering paradigm dependencies from the three dataset, thresholds were set as: S​u​p​p​o​r​tm​i​n=10𝑆𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑜𝑟subscript𝑡𝑚𝑖𝑛10Support_{min}=10, C​o​n​f​i​d​e​n​c​em​i​n=0.9𝐶𝑜𝑛𝑓𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑛𝑐subscript𝑒𝑚𝑖𝑛0.9Confidence_{min}=0.9, D​i​v​e​r​s​i​t​ym​i​n=5𝐷𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑡subscript𝑦𝑚𝑖𝑛5Diversity_{min}=5 and I​n​n​e​r​S​u​pm​i​n=5𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑟𝑆𝑢subscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛5InnerSup_{min}=5. As to the distance function d𝑑d, we specified zero distance for the same characters, and 0.50.50.5 for different ones but with the same type, 1.51.51.5 for ones with different type. For example, d(′a′,′a′)=0d(^{\prime}a^{\prime},^{\prime}a^{\prime})=0, d(′a′,′b′)=0.5d(^{\prime}a^{\prime},^{\prime}b^{\prime})=0.5 and d(′a′,′9′)=1.5d(^{\prime}a^{\prime},^{\prime}9^{\prime})=1.5.

Eventually, there were 333333, 919191 and 888 dependencies discovered from the Notebook, RAM and CPU dataset respectively. All these rules are verified true manually. With lower thresholds, the result set can grows much larger.

In Table V, several discovered dependencies are listed in three groups, with each group corresponding to a single dataset. The paradigm in the dependency is demonstrated in a compact format, actually it is a star-free Regular Expression: exactly one of the elements in braces ’{}\{\}’ is supposed to appear, and no more than one of elements in square brackets ’[][]’ is supposed, delimiters between optional elements are omitted to save space. The locations are marked by underlines for intuition.

Take the first dependency for example, for the CPU model I5, it means that the second element from backward can be a numeric digit from 00 to 999 except 888, and its value tells the model of video card integrated.

V-C Efficiency

On Real Datasets

We concern the running time, number of merging operations and number of refining operations in different methods. From Fig. 4 we can see that Baseline is of the highest number of merging, Pruning- reduced that by about two-thirds, and Pruning+ reduced it greatly.

However, in Fig. 5, the time consumption shows a quite different result: Pruning+ remained the most efficient, and Pruning- becomes very inefficient. That is because although some merging operations are saved, even much more time was wasted in the refining phase, maintaining necessary data structures becomes very costly if refining operation is too frequent. Fig. 6 shows comparison of the number of refining between Pruning+ and Pruning-.

In Fig. 7 are statistics of the number of refines in selecting the best pair of paradigms. It shows that on all of the three datasets, in most of the time, Pruning+ refined the critical set C​R𝐶𝑅CR only once (in Line 9 of Algorithm 3). Even in the worst case, only six refining operations were required.

On Synthetical Datasets In Fig. 8, the number of Baseline’s merging operations remains a constant, because it is unrelated to strings’ length. Pruning based methods can reduce the merging numbers to a great extent, especially Pruning+.

As it does on real datasets, Pruning- has the worst efficiency, as shown in Fig. 9.

Fig. 10 and 11 illustrate the number of mergings and time consumed in different algorithms, when varying the number of input strings (N𝑁N). It can be observed that Baseline’s merging number is proportional to N2superscript𝑁2N^{2}, and Pruning+ has almost linear time costs and merging operations, making it the best algorithm in efficiency.

From Fig. 12, it can be seen that by changing number of clusters, or the variation ratio σ𝜎\sigma, the running time of Baseline and Pruning+ did not change regularly.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, a new type of dependencies, Paradigm Dependencies has been proposed, in which the left hand side is part a regular expression like paradigm. To discover such dependencies, a framework has been proposed to align and cluster meaningful strings simultaneously. The aligning problem has been proved in NP-Complete, and a greedy algorithm was introduced in which the clustering and aligning tasks can be combined together seamlessly. Due to the greedy algorithm’s high time complexity, several pruning strategies with theoretical support were proposed to reduce the running time. Then discovery of paradigm dependencies on the generated paradigms have been defined and discussed, based on four measurements. Finally, our methods’ effectiveness and efficiency have been verified on three real world datasets as well as synthetical datasets.

For future work, we consider of several aspects: 1) In our framework, dependencies are discovered on already merged paradigms. Actually, correlations between a paradigm’s column and an attribute’s values can help aligning the strings more wisely. So by changing our two-step framework into a iterative and interactive one may improve the effectiveness to some extent. 2) Due to the high complexity, we consider of redesigning the greedy algorithm, e.g., by parallelization, or trading off between effectiveness and efficiency, etc. 3) In the discovering phase, we assumed a single position in the left hand side. Actually, it is possible that multiple elements together in a string indicate another attribute’s value, which makes the problem more complicated. 4) The purpose of introducing paradigm dependencies is to handle dirty data, so it is nature to study data cleaning problems, such as inconsistent data repairing and missing values imputation, using these new proposed rules.
